awd_titl_txt: Phase Transitions in Random Interacting Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project addresses several questions in discrete probability. The first is on random interacting systems of particles, which serve as probabilistic models for phenomena ranging from the spread of infections to the growth of populations of competing organisms. Even the simplest examples of such particle systems are not fully understood. This project is focused on a system in a larger family known as A + B -> 2B models studied by physicists as models for combustion. The system has recently been shown to display surprising behavior on finite and infinite trees, which this project will explore further. The other major question to be pursued is on random trees, another common model throughout the sciences. This project investigates equations arising from random trees whose solutions are related to the existence or nonexistence of certain classifications of trees into categories.

The first part of the project is to study a system of interacting random walks known as the frog model. In this process, inactive particles are placed on a graph. One particle then becomes active and performs a random walk, waking any particles it encounters. These particles then start their own random walks, waking any particles they encounter, and so on. Recent work by the PI has shown that the model exhibits phase transitions between transience and recurrence on infinite trees and between different cover time regimes on finite trees. The project proposes proving the existence of an additional weak recurrence phase on the infinite tree and an intermediate cover time phase on the finite tree. A potential route to this lies in further finer analysis of recursive distributional equations, working first with toy models. The other proposed project explores classifications of trees that follow rules given by automata. The prototypical example is the classification of trees according to whether they contain an infinite binary subtree starting at the root. This classification obeys a recursive rule (namely that a tree is in the class if and only if at least two root child subtrees are) that can be described by a tree automaton. This rule induces a fixed-point equation that one can use to compute the probability of a Galton-Watson tree being in this class. This project will investigate further the relationship between the classifications, the tree automata, and the fixed-point equations. Two approaches to the problem are probabilistic investigation of the random trees and other branching processes arising from them, and the direct analytic investigation of the fixed-point equations.

por.por_cntn:
This project helped to produce seven published research papers and one preprint. Five of the papers are on random systems of interacting particles. In systems of this sort, particles are placed in some setting (for example, a two-dimensional lattice) and then move at random and interact by predetermined rules. The first system studied in this project was the frog model. Here, all but one particle are initially asleep. The single active particle moves at random and wakes up any particles it encounters, which then wake up any particles they encounter, and so on. This system is sometimes called the A + B -> 2A model, with A representing an active particle and B representing a sleeping one. The other system studied, two-type annihilating random walk, is sometimes called the A + B -> 0 model: rather than one type of particle converting the other to its type, when two particles of the opposite type encounter each other both are annihilated. One can interpret these models in various ways—for example, the frog model could be thought of as explaining the spread of a rumor—and physicists in particular are interested in these and wider classes of particle system models. Some of the questions my coauthors and I investigate include: How quickly do the active particles in the frog model spread on an infinite tree? How long does it take for all particles to activate on a finite tree? How sensitive is the frog model to slight changes to the initial placement of the particles, as compared to other related particle models? For two-type annihilating random walks, does the behavior change if one class of particles moves more slowly than the others? 

Some of the other papers consider random trees representing, for example, a genealogy, with the root of the tree giving birth to a random quantity of children, each of whom independently gives birth to a random quantity of children, and so on. We consider properties that such a random tree might or might not have that have a certain type of recursive structure that comes up in many common examples. As the distribution of children of each node of the random tree is varied, these properties undergo phase transitions, where the probability of the random tree having the property suddenly starts increasing. Again, much of the interest comes from physicists, who are very interested in modeling real physical phase transitions by mathematical models. The phenomena that we discover might shed some light on phase transitions in the much less tractable models of statistical physics.

The project also provided opportunities for me to work with and mentor several undergraduate and graduate students (including students from groups underrepresented in mathematics). One of the published papers on two-type annihilating random walk includes two then undergraduates as coauthors, and I worked with with another two undergraduates on an as-of-yet unpublished summer project on the frog model. I also supervised a summer research project for a student as part of the NSF-funded LSAMP (Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation) program.
